article.description: With Maryland's Atlantic Coast Conference opener looming, John Gilchrist says the Terrapins have little margin for error.
article.headline: Maryland shoots season-high 55 percent from field
article.linkText: Gilchrist scores 20 in 2nd half, Maryland cruises
article.story: COLLEGE PARK, Md. (AP) -- With Maryland's Atlantic Coast Conference opener looming, John Gilchrist says the Terrapins have little margin for error. Even on a day when he missed only one shot, Gilchrist still found room for improvement in a lopsided victory. Gilchrist scored 20 of his 22 points in the second half and Maryland (No. 17 ESPN/USA Today, No 23 AP) was perfect from the free-throw line for just the second time in school history, cruising past North Carolina-Asheville 96-72 on Sunday. "We have to get over letting teams back in the game," said Gilchrist, whose team hosts Florida State in its conference opener Dec. 19. "With the ACC season starting, you have to put teams away." Travis Garrison and Chris McCray each added 15 points and D.J. Strawberry scored 13 for the Terrapins (5-2), who had lost two of three games. Maryland shot a season-high 55 percent from the field. Bryan McCullough had 16 points for UNC-Asheville (1-5), which was playing for the first time in eight days and coming off its first win of the season, over Western Carolina on Dec. 4. "I told our guys we've got to play the game closer to the vest -- and what I mean is, keep the game in the 70s so we have a chance to win," Bulldogs coach Eddie Biedenbach said. "We rebounded better, we did play better defense, but we didn't control the tempo of the game like I would have liked." Omar Collington scored 12 points for the Bulldogs. Gilchrist shook off a subpar first half to finish 8-for-9 form the field, 1-for-1 from 3-point range and 5-for-5 from the free-throw line. "John really plays well when he plays his game," Maryland coach Gary Williams said. "Sometimes, other things enter into his game and I think you saw that in the first half." The Terrapins, who entered the game shooting 68.5 percent from the free-throw line, finished a perfect 13-for-13. The only other time Maryland converted all of its free throws was a 19-for-19 effort against Holy Cross on Jan. 21, 1985. "We've had some guys who have missed some, but hopefully that's behind us," Williams said. "That's the way you look at free-throw shooting -- you can get on a roll either way and it's certainly hurt us the last couple of games." Maryland, which lost to then-unranked George Washington in the finals of the BB&T Classic on Dec. 5, quickly solved its offensive issues against UNC-Asheville, scoring the game's first 12 points. The Terrapins' transition game and halfcourt and motion offenses -- which struggled for consistency against George Washington -- all produced points in bunches, forcing the Bulldogs to play catch-up from the onset. But Maryland's defense did its part, too, pinning the Bulldogs into low-percentage shots and preventing UNC-Asheville from establishing any rhythm. "Today we emphasized coming in and playing tough defense and forcing them to take tough shots," Strawberry said. McCray had 11 first-half points, helping the Terrapins to a 45-34 lead. The Bulldogs shot 14-for-38 in the first half and missed their first 11 shots from the field. Mike Jones' 3-pointer put the Terps up 24-10 with 11:23 left in the first half, but UNC-Asheville rebounded with an 11-2 burst to get within 26-21. Ekene Ibekwe's three-point play then jump-started a 10-2 Maryland run, with McCray's baseline turnaround jumper making it 38-21.
